lines: chairman:  if there are no housekeeping matters,
mr lahiri, mr johnson, we can begin.
first with you, mr lahiri, on your closings.
closing submissions by mr lahiri
mr lahiri:  thank you, sir.  my greetings to everyone --
i know in different time zones.
there are, it seems to me, eight main issues in this
case.  i try and cover as many of them as i can, if the
time permits.  starting with the more substantive issues
and then going over to the ones where the written
closing submissions fairly address each others'
positions.
the first is: when was substantial completion
achieved and when was it supposed to be achieved?
the difference between these two dates would set the
limits for the days for which lds may be charged.
secondly: what was the critical path to the delayed
completion and who is responsible for such delays on the
critical path?
the answer to these will governed the period of
extension of time to which al hassan is entitled.
that then takes us to the third issue: is al hassan
entitled to an extension of time?  if so, how much?
conversely, if not, is hyundai entitled to liquidated
damages?
the last matter connected to delay is the issue of
prolongation costs.  this includes loss of contribution
to overheads and profit.  this we deal with in the
following two periods.
first, from the date of the supplementary
agreement -- which is 1 may 2011 -- until the date on
which substantial completion was achieved.  that's the
first period, and that's coterminous with any issue
of eot.
secondly, if the date for substantial completion is
earlier than 22 march 2014, then the second period of
prolongation costs is from the date that substantial
completion is achieved until 22 march 2014.
there is a difference between the parties, as
a matter of principle.  i will come to that later.
the fifth main issue is a fairly limited issue, on
the question of whether al hassan is entitled to payment
of its increased costs from omanisation -- i'll just use
that as shorthand.
chairman:  mr lahiri, can i just stop you for a moment.
mr umar, my realtime is not rolling automatically.
(discussion off the record)
chairman:  sorry, mr lahiri.  please continue.
mr lahiri:  not at all.  may i continue, sir?
i think i was at the fifth issue, which is
a relatively limited issue, which is whether al hassan
is entitled to its increased costs due to omanisation.
sixthly -- and now we are getting into the defences
and counterclaims -- whether al hassan wrongfully failed
to comply with its defects liability obligations.  if
so, is hyundai entitled to its counterclaims for the
additional cost of rectification of defects?
seventh: did al hassan wrongfully fail to carry out
parts of its scope of work and if so, is hyundai
entitled to counterclaims for additional cost of having
such works carried out?
finally -- this is quite a central issue taken, but
it applies to several of these matters -- does the
expert decision prevent the tribunal from determining
any of the above matters?
i have summarised issues which actually are divided
into a number of sub-issues, as you will have seen in
the agreed list of issues.  the claimant's closing
submission sets out its submissions, as you'll have
seen, in accordance with those list of issues.
the respondent does not follow exactly that
structure, but i believe most if not all of the issues
are covered.  so parties are addressing the tribunal on
the issues -- more or less on all the issues in the
agreed list of issues.
this is, however, a higher level view of the
global picture.
i first, then, take to the central question which
concerns everyone here, which is: when was substantial
completion achieved?
first, to start with: what is the meaning of
substantial completion?  it is now not in dispute that
the meaning of substantial completion is what the
subcontract, clause 8, defines substantial completion
to be.
i don't need to bring that up, unless the tribunal
would want me to, but the reference is d1/18.
it's essentially this.  when the works or part of
the works are completed, in accordance with the
subcontract, except for minor outstanding works, or
defects or omissions, which will not impede other main
contract works.
the definition of "substantial completion" in
clause 8 goes on to stipulate some further requirements,
such as the passing of performance tests or tests on
completion and the provision of documentation.
i believe those are not in issue in the present
case.  even though it is not characterised in hyundai's
closing as being a performance test, i suspect there
might be a suggestion in oral closing to suggest that
the leak test of the grp roof sheeting is such
a performance test.
so i will deal with the grp roof sheeting issue
anyway.  but as far as i'm aware, the real crux of the
dispute is whether substantial completion is achieved in
the context of the words i have spelt out in subcontract
clause 8.
so we are really looking at whether there is
compliance with the first part of the definition.
once the date on which that compliance is
determined, that is the date on which substantial
completion will be deemed or taken to have been
achieved.
what is al hassan's position on when substantial
completion is achieved?  its pleaded position was
substantial completion was achieved on 23 december 2012.
the reference in my closings is paragraph 185, ccs/185.
sir and members of the tribunal, i will use the
shorthand "ccs" and "rcs" to refer to our respective --
my learned friend's and my closing submissions.  so when
you see that on the transcript, you will know what
that is.
why is it 23 december?  not because any works were
completed on that date, but that was the date before the
final measurement was agreed between al hassan and
hyundai on 24 december 2012.  we can see that from
documents e/654 and e/657.
following the introduction of ms menon as a delay
expert in these proceedings and her opinion, al hassan
now considers and requests the tribunal to take as its
position, that substantial completion was achieved at an
earlier date than 23 december 2012 -- this date being no
later than 7 august 2012.
this is the date marked by both experts as the date
on which the primary substation on the main stp site was
substantially complete.
i will come on shortly to the list of dates that
hyundai has offered as to when substantial completion
was achieved.  but since all of those dates are later
than 7 august 2012, the question that the tribunal needs
to answer is whether as at 7 august 2012, there was any
work outstanding other than minor works, defects or
omissions which would not impede other main contract
works.
that's the question that the tribunal, in my
respectful submission, needs to answer.
by "other main contract works" -- which are the
words taken from subcontract clause 8 -- one means the
work of follow-on trades of subcontractors engaged by
hyundai to carry out other parts of hyundai's scope
of work.
the tribunal will recall -- and there's a reference
in my closing -- that mr rahman accepted that hyundai
itself did not carry out any work.  all its work was
subcontracted.
so the other main contract works are essentially
works carried out by these other subcontractors, such as
the e&m, the electromechanical subcontractor; the hvac,
the heating, ventilation and air conditioning
subcontractor; and the e&i, electrical and
instrumentation subcontractor.
the cross-reference is rahman's cross-examination,
day 3, page 108.
in other words, by when did al hassan, who as the
civils and architectural works subcontractor, was the
first in line of several follow-on trades -- when did
al hassan, as a civils and architectural works
subcontractor, finish its work to a sufficient extent to
allow the subsequent trades to commence their work?
one key piece of evidence in the examination of this
issue for the tribunal's determination, would be if
there are any valid complaints by other subcontractors
that al hassan was holding up their works?
the tribunal will note that not only is there no
evidence of such complaints, there is not even an
assertion by hyundai that al hassan held up the works of
other subcontractors beyond the date on which al hassan
says it achieved substantial completion, which is
7 august 2012.
that al hassan did not impede the other main
contract works can be corroborated by the following
further matters.  the reference is ccs/186.
first, the tribunal may recall i asked mr rahman:
"as far as impeding the work of other subcontractors
is concerned, the hvac contractor was already working in
the primary substation before august 2012; isn't that
correct?
answer:  yeah, of course.  there will be electrical
and hvac works going on in parallel."
reference transcript day 3, page 116, 19 to 24.
we can see from the contemporaneous reporting by
hyundai to higher water -- so this is up the line.
hyundai reporting to higher water as to progress
on-site.
here, sir, may i request the document controller to
raise k/217.
what it is, as we see at the bottom of the screen,
it's the weekly progress report for the period 2 june to
8 june.
if we go to the 10th page of this document, which is
21271, and if you scroll down to item 6, we can see that
under the heading, "civil & steel structure", it states:
"installation of hvac ducting inside primary
substation progressed at main stp."
that was what happened that week, and it was going
to continue in the "next week" column on the right:
"installation of hvac ducting inside primary
substation main stp to be continued."
when i subsequently put the proposition to
mr rahman, after showing him some weekly progress
reports from this time, and i asked him:
"to the extent it is considered by the tribunal that
the primary substation was the critical activity
delaying provisional completion, the evidence indicates
that for months before, hyundai's other subcontractors
were not being impeded from working in the primary
substation."
and mr rahman's answer was this:
"i disagree with that.  even without a door, without
installation of doors, other works will be going on.
you got my point?  without door, doors will be installed
at later stages.  there may be damage or due avoid
damages.  so what we need is a final substantial
completion.  all works should be fully completed in our
primary substation."
this is day 3.
in disagreeing with the proposition i put to
mr rahman, he has essentially confirmed the accuracy of
the proposition i put to him.
why?  because what he's talking about to support his
disagreement is not substantial completion, but
completion of the entirety of al hassan's scope, which
is a different concept.
secondly, by saying that hyundai would hold back
al hassan's installation of the doors -- and we know the
doors to the primary substation is an issue here.
by saying that hyundai would hold back al hassan's
installation of the doors until the other trades had
completed their work in the primary substation so that
the doors are not damaged by other trades -- something
that makes sense -- mr rahman has essentially confirmed
that the installation of the doors to the primary
substation is dependent on the completion of work by the
other subcontractors.
if that is the case, that installation of the doors
cannot mark al hassan's achievement of substantial
completion, because the works of the other
subcontractors are not under al hassan's control.
so that deals with the works and omissions of works
in the definition of "substantial completion".
what about defects?  when are defects minor or when
do they not impede?
mr naqvi was cross-examined about this.  he said:
"if the defect does not harm the other contractor to
start working on that, so it will be considered a minor
defect, because we are not obstructing the other trades'
works."
it seemed that counsel cross-examining him agreed
with that expression.  this is transcript day 2, 173:15
so even in relation to defects -- not just
outstanding work or omissions, but even in relation to
defects, it is along the same theme that mr rahman
spoke of.
it should not -- the outstanding work or the defects
should not impede the other subcontractors' work.
finally, the principal other subcontractor on this
job would have been the electromechanical subcontractor,
building the heart of the plant.  that's the process
that this plant is supposed to use.
they were called baek suk.  mr rahman spelt it out
for me: b-a-e-k, s-u-k.
mr rahman confirmed twice -- once on day 3, pages
52:4 to 52:12 and once on day 4, pages 63:15 to 63:24 --
that there were no issues of disputes between hyundai
and baek suk.
indeed, mr rahman did not need to confirm this.
hyundai itself has put in no evidence of any of the
other subcontractors bringing a claim against hyundai
because the subcontractor had been delayed by al hassan.
of course i'm not suggesting that once it can be
shown that al hassan took its works to a sufficient
stage of construction or completion that the work of the
other subcontractors was not impeded, that it could
simply call it a day.  of course not.  al hassan could
not.  it would have to complete any outstanding work,
which would be set out in a punch list, and defects
rectification.  it would need to do that before it could
properly say that it had completed its scope of work.
but the reason why there is this earlier stage of
completion called "substantial completion", and the
reason that it is defined as a stage of completion that
does not impede the follow-on subcontractors, is because
of the consequence of a delay in the achievement of
substantial completion.
the consequence of a delay in the achievement of
substantial completion is an exposure to liquidated
damages which, in effect, can wipe out 10 per cent of
a contractor's subcontract price.  ccs/12 and 13.
in other words, if al hassan's delayed achievement
of substantial completion led to the other
subcontractors making claims against hyundai, the lds
would be there to compensate hyundai for any amounts
hyundai would have to pay to those other subcontractors
for al hassan's delay.
that is the purpose of liquidated damages, and that
is why it is important to understand the link between
substantial completion on this project and liquidated
damages, and why substantial completion, particularly of
a civils and architectural works subcontractor, who's
the first in line of several follow-on trades -- why the
substantial completion of al hassan requires completion
not of the entirety of its scope, but completion to
a sufficient degree to enable the follow-on
subcontractors to proceed.
as i said, it is important to bear in mind that
al hassan is a civils and architectural subcontractor.
it is not the main contractor.  it is not even the last
contractor or subcontractor.  al hassan's works will be
the first to complete amongst the e&m, hvac and e&i
subcontractors.
al hassan's substantial completion cannot be on the
date on which hyundai achieves substantial completion
under its main contract with higher water, as hyundai
has sought to suggest in its pleaded case.  when it says
that al hassan's work achieved substantial completion on
24 june 2014, which is the date on which hyundai
achieved substantial completion under its main contract
because sewage was introduced on that date.  these two
are not coterminous.
this fact and mr rahman's evidence that i quoted
earlier, show that elements of al hassan's work that are
dependent on completion of follow-on trades work -- the
example mr rahman used was installation of doors.  those
elements of work cannot be required for al hassan's
achievement of substantial completion.
if they are -- assume they are.  assume the tribunal
finds that they are required for the achievement of
substantial completion.  then the tribunal must grant
al hassan an extension of time for the entire period
over which the other subcontractors are working until
al hassan can install the doors.  that has to follow.
that would not necessarily make sense.  and that is
why there is a distinction between works that are
required for substantial completion and works that are
required for overall completion.
finally on this issue, if one were to look at
hyundai's position contemporaneously stated -- not the
position it has formulated for the purposes of this
arbitration, but its contemporaneous position -- it can
be seen that hyundai too was of the view that al hassan
had achieved substantial completion by august 2012.
why do i say this?  i refer here to ccs/186.
on 24 september 2012, hyundai proposed the total
quantity measurement sheet, measuring total quantities
executed by al hassan, as stated on that letter.
total quantities in a re-measurement contract are
only issued at the end of a party's completion of its
scope.  this sheet was discussed between the parties.
a joint inspection took place in october 2012, and the
final quantities were agreed on 24 december 2012, as
i mentioned earlier.
there are no further quantity measurement sheets
after this date that parties discussed.  completion of
minor works, rectification of defects, et cetera, do not
necessitate a further measurement.  the quantities of
minor works and defects to works to be rectified are
already included in the total measured quantities.
completion of minor works and defects rectification
are matters of contractual obligation rather than
measurement.
on 24 december 2012 -- this is e/654 -- hyundai also
set out its calculation of the -- and i quote:
"... final payment for al hassan's civil and
architectural works."
which it said was -- open quote:
"... based on mutually agreed quantities duly
supported with quantity summary (as attached)."
somebody has kindly put that document up, e/654.  if
you could go down.
it says on the second line:
"... which shall be final payment for your civil and
architectural works.  this is based on mutually agreed
quantities with quantity summary (as attached)."
the only thing as you will see from that letter that
was outstanding, was al hassan's claim for outstanding
works, which hyundai says has not been discussed and
should be resolved later by discussions.
it's an important document, and it's an important
contemporaneous piece of evidence.
on 20 january 2013, so about three weeks after
this -- e/656, if somebody could raise it.
20 january 2013.  go down.
same sort of subject.  here hyundai is chasing
al hassan for its signature on the agreed measured
quantities:
"we are yet to receive your confirmation of the
agreed quantities duly signed and stamped on the
quantity measurement sheets (so far)."
second paragraph.
last paragraph:
"please note that this is the first and foremost
requirement in resolving issues before taking any next
step.  therefore, your confirmation is urgently
requested."
required in order to proceed further.
following this letter, four days later, on
24 january 2013, al hassan returned the signed
measurement sheets.  that's e/657.  we don't need to
bring that up.  that is just for the reference.
so we are now in late january 2013.  the tribunal
will remember that on 6 february 2013, there was
a meeting between the parties, which resulted in the now
famous or infamous 6 february 2013 agreement.
at that meeting to resolve issues, hyundai agreed to
a valuation of omani riyal 2.118 million for the work
done, as confirmed by these joint measurement sheets
that we have seen.
the joint measurement sheets, as i mentioned, had
been signed by both parties, by 24 january 2013, so just
about 10 days, two weeks prior to this meeting.
if we go to that 6 february 2013 agreement -- we
don't have to go to it, but the tribunal will know it.
i can take you to it, if necessary.
the only outstanding work listed in that agreement,
the tribunal will recall, are two: landscaping and
demolition of stp.
an agreed price is set out for al hassan to carry
out those works, should hyundai instruct al hassan to
carry out that work.  those are the only two items
listed on 6 february 2013 as being outstanding.
a few days after the 6 february 2013 agreement, on
9 february, hyundai issued its punch list for
outstanding work.
you will remember when i asked mr rahman about this,
he agreed that a punch list lists minor outstanding work
or omissions that al hassan needs to complete.
the cross-examination reference is day 3, 108:21
to 25.
the issuance by hyundai of the punch list is yet
another indication that hyundai considered that
al hassan's work was substantially complete -- not
entirely complete, as that was the purpose of the punch
list, but substantially complete.
after the 6 february 2013 agreement, hyundai did
make claims for the cost of rectification of defects,
and the additional cost of work that it says al hassan
refused to complete.
but none of those elements of work in hyundai's
counterclaim -- five defective works and ten incomplete
work -- are relied upon by hyundai as having held up
achievement of substantial completion of
al hassan's work.
none of those matters.  the counterclaim is only one
for cost.
i have taken the tribunal through al hassan's
position and the corroborative evidence that suggests
that al hassan did, indeed, achieve substantial
completion by 7 august 2012.
that brings us nicely to examining on which day
hyundai says substantial completion was achieved.
as we have set out, and the tribunal will have seen
from ccs/187, this has been a smorgasbord of dates.
the pleaded position was 24 june 2014, but even that
was not on the basis that al hassan achieved substantial
completion on that date.  it was said it is because
hyundai achieved substantial completion of al hassan's
work through others -- if there is such a thing.
the position of al hassan's substantial completion
being 24 june 2014 was also the position taken in the
respondent's opening submissions at paragraph 121.
then we come to a fascinating subject: mr dale.
mr dale has had a journey through a bouquet of dates.
we have already described that in ccs/187,
subparagraph (a)(8).  so even with mr dale, it was not
particularly clear when he said substantial completion
was achieved.
finally, in its closing submissions, hyundai's
position has changed from its previous position, and it
now says substantial completion was achieved on
3 december 2013.  rcs, paragraphs 136 and 221(5).
but even that seems to be still a movable feast, as
there is a suggestion in rcs, paragraph 146, that the
date of substantial completion may even be later than
that, on 22 january 2024 -- a date mentioned by no one
until the respondent's closing submissions were served.
because on that date, there was a grp leak test at
a treated effluent facility in al mubela.  rcs/143,
sub (8).
it is not clear to me where all this is leading to
but, for completeness, i mention it.  i will come back
to this later when i look at roof leak tests.
so at least now we can proceed and the tribunal can
proceed, for present purposes, that we are looking at
3 december 2013 as hyundai's position on when
substantial completion was achieved.
why this date?  it is because there is an inspection
record for 22 steel doors of the primary substation
listed in the inspection register against this date.
when was this brought up as date for substantial
completion?  for the first time in mr dale's errata
served, if i recall, three or four days before the start
of the hearing -- some two years after his last report.
where does one find a critical path analysis that
leads to whatever happened on 3 december 2013?  there
is none.
the tribunal had directed on 31 january 2020, that
both parties' cases are to be confined to the causes of
delay or concurrent delay identified in their respective
pleadings: h30/392.
by trying to advance a new cause of delay -- being
the late inspection of steel doors for the primary
substation.
this is h30/392.  somebody has brought that up.
(the hearing was adjourned to the following day)
